comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: I'd love to know where, looks like north of Wombeyan Caves road and closer to (or at) Burragorang Valley.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] I had a whizz up and down the valley using Google Earth and Street View but found nothing conclusive. I did find this strange horse standing on a bridge - maps.google.com.au/maps?ll=-34.308209,150.072129&spn=...

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] My guess it that it is now underwater and is now the floor of the Warragamba Dam. The rising topography is a clue to this. Maybe the imminent flooding prompted the recording of the view for the last time.

Your Streetview reference is the bridge/causeway of Wombeyan caves road not far from my location.

I love the horse. It prompts me to get a similar plastic one and have it appear on many Streetview photos as a practical joke...lol. It looks in such poor condition I'd bet it's a tame brumby as there are frequent campsites at that location.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] What a surreal street view capture!

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: The Dam was flooded around 1960, a long while after the glass plate was taken so there is no direct relationship in time. Though it still looks to me like the location where the dam is today.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] I do not know the area at all so I can offer no help.  The valleys looks terrific in these old photos.

Most of the Charles Kerry photos with that 'jaunty' script (as I call it) seem to be ca. 1910.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] That's a fun photo at a time when taking photos was a very serious affair.

comment.author: 50615476@N03
comment._content:
Using Google Earth, I'm pretty confident this is looking down the Cox's River towards the junction with the Wollondilly which flows in from the right beyond the spur which diagonally crosses the photo from top right horizon to mid-upper left. That spur drops off the end of Bimlow Tableland.
The mountain on the left horizon is beyond the junction,and is part of the escarpmented NW end of the Burragorang Tableland.
Just beyond the house is a crossing of the Cox's known as Storey's Crossing on the old parish maps. Using the 1899 parish map Bimlow,County of Westmoreland,the house may possibly be on portion 5,held by a John Seymour.  Between the house and the Bimlow tableland spur is the tributary valley of Green Wattle Creek.

Judging by the low and uniform heights of the River Oaks lining the pools, a massive flood has come down the river not long before the photo was taken,perhaps no longer than three years. Might this help date the photo? 
This area is now submerged by the dam.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/50615476@N03] I agree with your River Oaks speculation, there do look so uniform suggesting a flood event.

comment.author: 50615476@N03
comment._content: I read of a very large flood along the Nepean at Penrith and below in July 1900. Perhaps that is the one?  By the 13/7/1900,300mm of rain had been recorded at Lawson. The storm event brought very heavy snow [enough to collapse roofs and break tree limbs] to the central and northern tablelands as well.

comment.author: 50615476@N03
comment._content:
Descriptions of damage along the Nepean suggest a devastating and powerful flood which reshaped river banks,scoured out basins,deposited 4 to 8 feet of sand and gravel through farms and destroyed infrastructure that had withstood all previous floods. 

The above photo shows some very thoroughly scoured banks as well as the absence of large River Oaks.

comment.author: 50615476@N03
comment._content: Also a very similar flood in July 1904.
